awd_titl_txt: HNDS-I: Collaborative Research: Developing a Data Platform for Analysis of Nonprofit Organizations
awd_abstract_narration:
Nonprofit organizations are important contributors to the US economy and social well-being. Across a wide range of domains, such as healthcare, childcare, education, job training, and many others, nonprofit organizations serve the public, reduce the costs of government, and improve daily lives. Millions of individuals interact with nonprofit organizations every day. Yet despite these important roles, the high costs of collecting and sharing data have prevented a greater understanding of nonprofit organizations and their collective contributions to society. This project, the Nonprofit Organization Research Panel Project (NORPP) Manager, will create a publicly-accessible, internet-based, and collaborative research platform that will lower the costs of collecting and sharing large amounts of high-quality, multiyear data on nonprofits and their impacts. The platform will strengthen research and evaluation, broaden access to data-intensive research, and lead to more scientifically informed decision-making by organizations, policymakers, and funders and to improved outcomes for the communities they serve.

The NORPP platform will offer three primary functions. First, tools and automated processes will allow researchers to recruit and grow representative samples of nonprofit organizations nationally and across communities, states, and regions over time using a common methodology. The platform will automate systematic sampling and weighting procedures to ensure representativeness for studies using the platform, and it will reduce other costs to researchers by automating information flows with organizations in its samples. It will also allow public access among the research and practice communities to download nationally representative data, build additional project-specific samples within the platform, add original survey instruments, and collect original data. Second, the NORPP Manager will support the merger of data developed within the platform with IRS Form 990 Data and other available data on organizations from the population of 501(c)(3) nonprofit organizations that file with the IRS, including geocoded data on organizations’ communities and external environment that are publicly available from Census and other sources. Third, the NORPP Manager will serve as a collaborative repository to manage a bank of core and supplemental questionnaires to facilitate replication studies, improve content validity of measurements, and allow for consistent measurement scales across nonprofit organizational research. This work will increase the efficiency of research on nonprofit organizations by significantly reducing the costs to sample, contact, and survey nonprofit organizations, and to merge those data with existing data with the goal of facilitating the growth of rigorous, data-intensive research across the many social science disciplines that intersect with nonprofit organizational research.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The 1.9 million nonprofit organizations in the United States play a vital role delivering services, strengthening communities, and facilitating civic engagement. Nonprofit data providers like the National Center for Charitable Statistics (NCCS) at the Urban Institute, Candid, and ProPublica have built a rich data ecosystem using publicly available administrative tax records. Although these data have transformed our understanding of the nonprofit sector, they are inherently limited by the information collected on Internal Revenue Service Form 990 (the  main tool the IRS uses to collect information from tax-exempt organizations), which does not ask organizations about changes in their programs and services or the evolving needs of their communities. And although many researchers are interested in collecting more information from nonprofits to improve knowledge about strengths and challenges, there are large costs, capacity constraints, and collaboration barriers that impede high-quality original data collection.

This project, a collaboration between American University, George Mason University, the Georgia Institute of Technology, and the Urban Institute, sought to fill these gaps by developing a nationally representative data infrastructure that would

  • help answer how and why questions and dig deeper into nonprofit needs and strengths in serving communities;
  • increase researcher access to high-quality data;
  • save researchers time by prelinking survey data to the IRS 990 data, US Census Bureau American Community Survey data, and other sources; and
  • allow for comparable analyses that could build cumulative knowledge.

When we began the project, one goal was to create a data warehouse (identified in our original proposal as the NORPP Manager) separate from the NCCS data where data could be combined and shared. We pursued this option after speaking with many researchers and organizations. During the project, the capabilities of the organization housing the NCCS changed, and we learned that data-privacy issues were a major barrier to maintaining all the details of the collected survey data linked to the other data sources elsewhere. The multiple years of grant funding and multidisciplinary collaboration allowed us to explore many options. The resulting open data platform now housed at the NCCS accomplishes the original goals of the project and has already been used by several organizations and researchers in the fields of economics, sociology, political science, management, public administration and policy, demography, tax policy, and finance to produce published analyses about

  • workforce issues, such as nonprofit employees, worker well-being, compensation, and impacts of the Paycheck Protection Program;
  • community-representation issues, such as the extent to which the gender and race of nonprofit leaders reflect the communities they serve; and
  • civil-society vibrancy as reflected by volunteering and the financial health of the nonprofit sector, including the effects of COVID-19 on the sector.

The analyses noted above used the other products of this grant: data from the National Survey of Nonprofit Trends and Impacts. Funding from NSF under this grant and other funders allowed us to collaboratively develop and field three rounds of the survey (January to April 2021, April to September 2022, and November 2023 to March 2024). These data were collected from nationally representative groups of operating 501(c)(3) public charities in the United States whose activities range from direct service provision to community building and advocacy. The survey asked organizations about their characteristics (their nonprofit subsector and size), their programs (who they serve and where), their staff and volunteer numbers and demographics, the importance of donations and volunteers, their fundraising and finances, and other important questions related to their responses to the pandemic.

The data warehouse developed through this project thus houses new publicly available resources for building knowledge about the nonprofit sector. Trained researchers who can meet required data-privacy standards can also access restricted-use data with even more details about the nonprofits in the samples and the communities they serve. The public can freely access information to replicate the sampling process, conduct similar surveys, and analyze the data.

In the short term, we can observe the usefulness of this project in 29 peer-reviewed studies that have already cited or used the data, 44 articles and reports from news outlets and nonprofit organizations, and regular inquiries from people interested in how the data could be used to support their work. In the medium term, we are working with foundations, nonprofits, and policymakers to create dashboards and reports that support better evidence-based practices in philanthropy and nonprofit management. In the long term, we expect these outcomes to create greater sustainability for nonprofits and better results for the people and communities they serve.

All project deliverables, including reports, research guides, datasets, data dictionaries, survey questions, and Qualtrics files, are accessible on the NCCS website at

https://urbaninstitute.github.io/nccs/resources/nonprofit-trends-and-impacts/.
